posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: My team just got a new battery analyzer/disharger and I was wondering what we need to look at to determine the quality of our batteries.

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

posts.cooked:
We typically evaluate internal resistance, considering a good range between 0.018 and 0.022. Any value exceeding 0.03 is problematic. Additionally, we remove the top four values we identify annually.  

It’s also important to check the charge level when your charger indicates it’s full; ideally, it should reach close to 130%. Any level below approximately 100% is considered subpar for our purposes.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
The text is:

EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.
The text is:

There’s some good info on the CBA product page.

Start with the battery fully charged. Set it to discharge at the max (7.5 A) down to 10.5V. Record the total energy, and also look at the voltage graph and make sure it doesn’t have a sudden drop of 1.5 to 2V in the middle of the discharge because that indicates a bad cell. It generally takes about 90 minutes for a full test.

Grade your batteries by total energy delivered over the test.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: There are MANY threads from the last few years on this topic. As far as I know this is the most recent thread on the topic: Computerized Battery Analyzer. If you know another battery analyzer like this that does the same job just cheaper let me know! If you know another way to check your battery it will also be very helpful.

posts.name: Michael Anderson
posts.cooked: Starting a new thread on this topic. Testing methods include the BD250 discharger, cold crank amp tester (carbon pile load tester), and battery beak. The BD250 is primarily used to assess battery capacity and health, formatted to 20 A until a terminating voltage of 10.8. Batteries are tested and ranked before competition. The battery beak offers quick and easy testing. No effective use has been found for the cold crank amp test. Correlations between cold crank amp test results and BD250 capacity were not identified. Suggestions welcomed. Frequent brown-outs occur during competition; uncertainty exists if they result from battery limitations or bot demand exceeding battery capacity. Questions include flaws in the testing approach, methods to measure battery load during competition, and potential programs simulating standardized bot operations to evaluate battery capability. Appreciate comments, enjoying the forum.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
Wondering whether anyone has developed a way to measure the load on the battery during compete. For instance, logging the current draw from the battery during compete, calculating the area under the current versus time curve for that specific competition, and using this as a method to determine the total load on the battery during that match.  

The driver station logs will indicate the total energy in kJ consumed during the match, found in the same section where you can view voltage and current logs.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: We have no way to test the batteries in a competition-like condition. Has anyone ever developed a program that cycles the bot through a standardized set of motions and operations to a predetermined cutoff voltage, and used the time to that cutoff voltage to rank the battery capability? This may be overkill, but the concept is one that is interesting to toy around with. You may find this paper interesting.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: A cold crank test (100 amps or more for 10 seconds) will identify a failed cell. Failed cells won’t appear on a battery pack check but will on a capacity test. Just after waiting a long time…

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I prefer to test at 50 Amps (the rating for the SB50) to better simulate actual use and to pull down the test time.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
The Hot-Plug or wire-to-board continuous rating is 120A for wire-to-wire operations, excluding hot-plugging under nominal conditions. For intermittent loads, ratings exceed this threshold, reflecting the nature of electrical engineering challenges—thermal management depends on both heat and duration. Our robot application falls within this higher range.  

We conduct annual capacity testing using an iCharger458 Duo instead of BD testers. This setup provides a realistic approximation of low to medium robot electrical loads. To simplify subsequent analyses and calculations, we aim for a 100A rating, though obtaining such a battery capacity tester is either unavailable or requires custom modifications, which we currently cannot pursue due to time constraints.  

Mid-season, if a battery shows signs of weakness, capacity testing becomes prudent; however, this is our inaugural year of extensive testing, so such situations haven't occurred yet. We are exploring periodic measurement strategies during competition and developing reliable methods to log and integrate match power data alongside other metrics, aiming to produce a real-time health monitoring system for the batteries.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Making my own, I have to say that 50 Amps is a lot of heat Its a huge heat sink with a solid fan on it

We do the exact same thing. Same measurements, same internal resistance, same charge percent. Our brownout issues went down a lot. Before we tested our batteries, we accidentally grabbed batteries that had been used or were bad. Highly recommend the advice from @FinIce.

posts.name: Michael Anderson
posts.cooked: Wondering whether anyone has developed a way to measure the load on the battery during competition. For example, logging the current draw from the battery during competition, finding the area under the current vs time curve for that particular competition, and using this as a method to measure total load on that battery during that match. The driver station logs will tell you the total energy in KJ during the match, in the same area where you view the voltage and current logs. Checking on this. Thank you.

posts.cooked: I will read, thank you.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: We are getting close to logging match energy onto RFID tags on the battery, easily readable with your phone.

posts.name: Michael Anderson
posts.cooked: That seems like an impressive solution. How is the data entered into the tag?

The Anderson SB50 connector datasheet includes a screenshot from https://www.andersonpower.com/content/dam/app/ecommerce/product-pdfs/SB50/ds-sb50.pdf. Page 3 features charts of temperature performance. The document also provides a link to a technical note explaining how to read these charts at https://www.andersonpower.com/content/dam/app/site/resources/techreference/ppmptecref.pdf. Temperature ratings vary based on standards; the UL 1977 standard specifies testing with constant current for 4 hours to prevent exceeding insulator temperatures and causing 150% rated current breakage 50 times. While the latest UL standard may differ minimally, Anderson's technical note indicates CSA standards allow only a 30°C rise above 25°C ambient. Generally, putting more than 50 amps through an Anderson SB50 connector is acceptable since 50 amps is a conservative rating applicable across most FRC conditions.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: USB RFID reader developed by the vision computer. Still a work in progress...

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I once hooked a SB50 pair to a spot welder to "condition" the terminals and see if a good hit of current made the resistance lower. The answer was "no", but the wires jumping due to the current/magnetic forces was cool! Check out the video below.
